thread.title: Why did Norwegian drop "Iron Chef"?

author: Fran Golden, Special for USA TODAY
title: Why did Norwegian drop "Iron Chef"?
text:
Chef Geoffrey Zakarian attends The New York Times Presents American Harvest Organic Vodka's Greenmarket Brunch. (Photo: Ben Gabbe, Getty Images for NYCWFF)
Tags Food Network Norwegian Breakaway Norwegian Cruise Line Norwegian Escape Norwegian Getaway 2 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Chef Geoffrey Zakarian, an "Iron Chef" and judge on Food Network's "Chopped," no longer has a restaurant at sea.
Norwegian Cruise Line said its deal with the celebrity chef to operate specialty restaurants Ocean Blue and The Raw Bar on the 4,000-passenger Norwegian Breakaway and sister ship Norwegian Getaway quietly ended a few months ago.
"After several successful years, Norwegian's engagement with Chef Geoffrey Zakarian has concluded," the cruise line said in a statement to USA TODAY. "Geoffrey has been a great partner and we are very appreciative of his work to create a luxury dining experience on our newest vessels."
Zakarian's land-based restaurants include The Lambs Club in New York. Last month, the chef said he said he was backing out of opening a restaurant in a new Donald Trump hotel project in light of the presidential candidate's remarks about Mexican immigrants.
READ MORE: Iron Chef chops Trump
Sans Zakarian, Norwehian is continuing to operate Ocean Blue and has expanded the restaurant's menu, the line said. The current per person price of $39.95 will change to a la carte pricing on October 3. Dishes at The Raw Bar have always been a la carte.
The line has a deal with another "Iron Chef," Philadelphia-based Jose Garces, for a Latin seafood restaurant and tapas bar on the soon-to debut, 4,200-passenger Norwegian Escape.
